item.title: Learning Golang (some rough notes) - S01E04 - Function Closures
item.description:
üëâ A Tour of Go : Function Closures

So far the Tour has been ü§î and üßê and even ü§® but function closures had me ü§Ø ‚Ä¶

Each of the words on the page made sense but strung together in a sentence didn’t really make any sense to me.

item.title: Learning Golang (some rough notes) - S01E03 - Maps
item.description:
üëâ A Tour of Go : Exercise - Maps

Implement WordCount

This is probably bread-and-butter for any seasoned programmer, but I enjoyed the simple process and satisfaction of breaking the problem down into steps to solve using what the tutorial had just covered. Sketching out the logic in pseudo-code first, I figured that I wanted to do this:

item.title: Learning Golang (some rough notes) - S01E02 - Slices

Note
 Learning Go : Background

üëâ A Tour of Go : Slices

Slices made sense, until I got to Slice length and capacity. Two bits puzzled me in this code:

item.title: Learning Golang (some rough notes) - S01E01 - Pointers
item.description:
Note
 Learning Go : Background

üëâ A Tour of Go : Pointers

I’ve never used pointers before. Found plenty of good resources about what they are, e.g.

  • https://www.callicoder.com/golang-pointers/

  • https://dave.cheney.net/2017/04/26/understand-go-pointers-in-less-than-800-words-or-your-money-back

But why? It’s like explaining patiently to someone that 2+2 = 4, without really explaining why would we want to add two numbers together in the first place.

item.title: Learning Golang (some rough notes) - S01E00
item.description: My background is not a traditional CompSci one. I studied Music at university, and managed to wangle my way into IT through various means, ending up doing what I do now with no formal training in coding, and a grab-bag of hacky programming attempts on my CV. My weapons of choice have been BBC Basic, VBA, ASP, and more recently some very unpythonic-Python. It’s got me by, but I figured recently I’d like to learn something new, and several people pointed to Go as a good option.
